company.name: EMP MEDIA, INC.
company.business_description: EMP Media operated a website dedicated to revenge porn or nonconsensual pornography, including the posting of intimate images and personal information without consent. The company also operated under multiple assumed names including MyEx.com, Post My Ad, T & A Media, and Internet Secrets.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

complaint.factual_background: Defendants operated MyEx.com, a revenge porn website that solicited and publicly posted intimate images of individuals alongside their personal information without consent. The website encouraged ex-partners to submit explicit photos and videos with identifying details including names, addresses, social media profiles, and employers. Defendants then extorted victims by charging fees of $499 to $2,800 to remove the content, generating over $4 million in revenue from January 2014 through April 2016.

counts.title: Unfair Public Disclosure of Personal Information
counts.representation: Defendants solicit intimate images and personal information from ex-partners of individuals depicted in the images, and disclose, without the consent of the individuals depicted, these intimate images and personal information on a website that enables the public to identify or contact the individuals depicted.
counts.fact: Defendants' acts and practices have caused or are likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that consumers cannot reasonably avoid themselves and that are not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants' practices as described in Paragraph 55 above constitute unfair acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 45(n).

counts.title: Unfair Charging of Removal Fees
counts.representation: In numerous instances, Defendants have charged or have caused others to charge consumers fees of $499 or more to remove intimate images and personal information from a public website, which Defendants solicited and disclosed without the consent of the individual depicted, in a way that enabled the public to identify or contact the individuals in the intimate images.
counts.fact: Defendants' acts or practices have caused or are likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that consumers cannot reasonably avoid themselves and that are not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants' practices as described in Paragraph 58 above constitute unfair acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 45(n).

counts.title: Deceptive Trade Practice - Coercion
counts.representation: Defendants knowingly used coercion, duress or intimidation in a transaction when, as described in Paragraphs 13 through 52 above, they sought payment from consumers to take down the personal information and intimate images of consumers they had posted on their publicly available website.
counts.fact: Nevada Revised Statute § 598.0923(4) states that it is a deceptive trade practice when, in the course of his or her business or occupation, a person knowingly uses coercion, duress or intimidation in a transaction.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, each of the Defendants' act or practices that used coercion, duress or intimidation in a transaction is a violation of Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, NRS § 598.0923(4).

definitions.Asset: Any legal or equitable interest in, right to, or claim to, any real, personal, or intellectual property, including without limitation, chattels, goods, instruments, equipment, fixtures, general intangibles, leaseholds, contracts, mail or other deliveries, shares or stock, securities, inventory, checks, notes, accounts, credits, receivables, insurance policies, lines of credit, cash, trusts (including asset protection trusts), lists of Consumer names and reserve funds or any other accounts associated with any payments processed by, or on behalf of, the Defendant, including such reserve funds held by payment processors, credit card processors, banks, or other Financial Institutions.
definitions.Clear and conspicuous: A required disclosure is difficult to miss (i.e., easily noticeable) and easily understandable by ordinary consumers, including in all of the following ways: 1. In any communication that is solely visual or solely audible, the disclosure must be made through the same means through which the communication is presented. In any communication made through both visual and audible means, such as a television advertisement, the disclosure must be presented simultaneously in both the visual and audible portions of the communication even if the representation requiring the disclosure is made in only one means. 2. A visual disclosure, by its size, contrast, location, the length of time it appears, and other characteristics, must stand out from any accompanying text or other visual elements so that it is easily noticed, read, and understood. 3. An audible disclosure, including by telephone or streaming video, must be delivered in a volume, speed, and cadence sufficient for ordinary consumers to easily hear and understand it. 4. In any communication using an interactive electronic medium, such as the Internet or software, the disclosure must be unavoidable. 5. The disclosure must use diction and syntax understandable to ordinary consumers and must appear in each language in which the representation that requires the disclosure appears. 6. The disclosure must comply with these requirements in each medium through which it is received, including all electronic devices and face-to-face communications. 7. The disclosure must not be contradicted or mitigated by, or inconsistent with, anything else in the communication. 8. When the representation or sales practice targets a specific audience, such as children, the elderly, or the terminally ill, 'ordinary consumers' includes reasonable members of that group.
definitions.Intimate Image: Any image exposing genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or female nipples or depicting a sex act.
definitions.Financial Institution: Any bank, savings and loan institution, credit union, or any financial depository of any kind, including brokerage house, trustee, broker-dealer, escrow agent, title company, commodity trading company, or precious metal dealer.
definitions.Personal Information: Information from or about an individual depicted in an Intimate Image.

provisions.title: Prohibition on Dissemination of Intimate Images and Personal Information Posted Without Consent
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from disseminating Intimate Images or Personal Information through websites or online services without providing clear notice and obtaining verifiable affirmative express written consent from each individual depicted.

requirements.description: Must not disseminate Intimate Images or Personal Information without clear and conspicuous notice to each individual depicted
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that Defendant, whether acting directly or indirectly, in connection with the advertising, marketing, promoting, distributing, offering for sale, or sale of any good or service, is permanently restrained and enjoined from disseminating, through a website or online service, Intimate Image(s) or Personal Information without: A. A clear and conspicuous notice, and not as part of a "privacy policy," "terms of use," or similar document posted on a website or online service, directly to each individual depicted in the Intimate Image, that Defendant will disseminate the Intimate Image and Personal Information through a website or online service

requirements.description: Must obtain verifiable affirmative express written consent from each individual depicted prior to dissemination and provide right to revoke consent
requirements.quoted_text: obtaining verifiable affirmative express consent in writing directly from each individual depicted in the Intimate Image prior to dissemination and also provide each individual the right to revoke consent at any time.

provisions.title: Disposition of Personal Information and Intimate Images
provisions.summary: Defendant must destroy all Personal Information and Intimate Images obtained without consent within 30 days and is prohibited from selling, using, or benefiting from such information.

requirements.description: Must not sell, rent, lease, disclose, use, transfer, or benefit from Personal Information or Intimate Images obtained without consent
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from directly or indirectly: A. selling, renting, leasing, disclosing, using, transferring, or otherwise benefitting from Personal Information or Intimate Images obtained without verifiable affirmative express consent in writing

requirements.description: Must destroy all Personal Information and Intimate Images obtained without consent in all forms in Defendant's possession
requirements.quoted_text: failing to destroy such Personal Information or Intimate Images in all forms in Defendant's possession, custody, or control within 30 days after entry of this Order.

provisions.title: Prohibition on Charging Takedown Fees
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently prohibited from charging consumers any fee related to taking down or removing Personal Information or Intimate Images from any website.

requirements.description: Must not charge any consumer any fee related to taking down or removing Personal Information or Intimate Images from any website
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from charging or assisting in charging any consumer any fee related to taking down or removing Personal Information or Intimate Images from any website, whether directly or through an intermediary.

provisions.title: Additional Conduct Prohibitions
provisions.summary: Defendant is prohibited from setting up merchant processing accounts or serving as an officer, director, or manager of any business unless Defendant actually controls, participates in, or has knowledge of the daily operations.

requirements.description: Must not set up or facilitate merchant processing accounts for any business entity unless Defendant actually controls, participates in, or has knowledge of the daily operations
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant, whether acting directly or through an intermediary, is permanently restrained and enjoined from: A. Setting up or facilitating merchant processing accounts for any business entity, unless Defendant actually controls, participates in, or has knowledge of the daily operations of that entity

requirements.description: Must not serve as an officer, director, or manager of any business entity unless Defendant actually controls, participates in, or has knowledge of the ordinary operations
requirements.quoted_text: Serving as an officer, director, or manager of any business entity, unless Defendant actually controls, participates in, or has knowledge of the ordinary operations of that entity.

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Partial Suspension
provisions.summary: Judgment of $205,000 is entered against Defendant, with $15,000 to be paid immediately and the remainder suspended based on truthfulness of financial representations.

requirements.description: Judgment of $205,000 entered in favor of Plaintiffs against Defendant
requirements.quoted_text: Judgment in the amount of $205,000.00 is entered in favor of the Plaintiffs against Defendant Infante.

requirements.description: Defendant must pay $15,000 to the Commission
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant is ordered to pay to the Commission fifteen thousand Dollars ($15,000), which, as Defendant stipulates, his undersigned counsel holds in escrow for no purpose other than payment to the Commission. Such payment must be made within 7 days of entry of this Order by electronic fund transfer in accordance with instructions previously provided by a representative of the Commission.

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all rights to assets transferred pursuant to this Order, and money paid may be used for equitable relief including consumer redress.

requirements.description: Defendant must relinquish dominion and all legal and equitable right, title, and interest in all assets transferred pursuant to this Order
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant relinquishes dominion and all legal and equitable right, title, and interest in all assets transferred pursuant to this Order and may not seek the return of any assets.

provisions.title: Cooperation
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with Plaintiffs in this case and related investigations by providing truthful information, evidence, testimony, and appearing for proceedings upon reasonable notice.

requirements.description: Must fully cooperate with Plaintiffs and provide truthful and complete information, evidence, and testimony; must appear for interviews, discovery, hearings, trials, and other proceedings upon 5 days written notice
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant must fully cooperate with representatives of Plaintiffs in this case and in any investigation related to or associated with the transactions or the occurrences that are the subject of the Complaint. Defendant must provide truthful and complete information, evidence, and testimony. Defendant must appear for interviews, discovery, hearings, trials, and any other proceedings that a Plaintiff representative may reasonably request upon 5 days written notice, or other reasonable notice, at such places and times as a Plaintiff representative may designate, without the service of a subpoena.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain acknowledgments of receipt of this Order from himself, business personnel, and others, and submit these acknowledgments to the Commission.

requirements.description: Defendant must submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of this Order sworn under penalty of perjury
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant, within seven (7) days of entry of this Order, must submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of this Order sworn under penalty of perjury.

requirements.description: For three years, for any business Defendant owns or controls, must deliver copy of Order to all principals, officers, directors, LLC managers and members, employees, agents, and representatives who participate in conduct related to the Order, and any business entity resulting from change in structure
requirements.quoted_text: For three (3) years after entry of this Order, for any business that Defendant individually or collectively with any other defendant named in this matter is the majority owner or controls directly or indirectly, Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to (1) all principals, officers, directors, and LLC managers and members; (2) all employees, agents, and representatives who participate in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure as set forth in the Section titled Compliance Reporting. Delivery must occur within 7 days of entry of this Order for current personnel. For all others, delivery must occur before they assume their responsibilities.

requirements.description: Must obtain signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of Order from each individual or entity to which Order was delivered
requirements.quoted_text: From each individual or entity to which Defendant delivered a copy of this Order, Defendant must obtain, within thirty (30) days, a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit compliance reports one year after entry of Order and provide compliance notices within 14 days of specified changes for twenty years.

requirements.description: One year after entry of Order, must submit compliance report sworn under penalty of perjury identifying contact information, businesses, business activities, involvement in businesses, compliance with Order, and Order Acknowledgments
requirements.quoted_text: One (1) year after entry of this Order, Defendant must submit a compliance report, sworn under penalty of perjury, which must: 1. Identify all of Defendant's telephone numbers and all physical, postal, and email and Internet addresses, including all residences, and identify the primary physical, postal, and email address and telephone number as designated points of contact, which representatives of the Plaintiffs may use to communicate with Defendant; 2. Identify all of the Defendant's businesses by all of their names, telephone numbers, and physical, postal, email, and Internet addresses; 3. Identify all business activities, including any business for which Defendant performs services whether as an employee or otherwise and any entity in which Defendant has any ownership interest; 4. Describe in detail Defendant's involvement in each such business, including title, role, responsibilities, participation, authority, control, and any ownership; 5. Describe the activities of each business, including the goods and services offered, the means of advertising, marketing, and sales; 6. Describe in detail whether and how the Defendant is in compliance with each Section of this Order; and 7. Provide a copy of each Order Acknowledgment obtained pursuant to this Order, unless previously submitted to the Commission.

requirements.description: For twenty years after entry of Order, must submit compliance notice within 14 days of changes in name or residence address, designated point of contact, title or role in any business, or structure of any entity Defendant owns or controls
requirements.quoted_text: For twenty (20) years after entry of this Order, Defendant must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within 14 days of any change in the following: 1. Name, including aliases or fictitious names, or residence address; 2. Any designated point of contact; 3. Title or role in any business activity, including any business for which Defendant performs services whether as an employee or otherwise and any entity in which Defendant has any ownership interest, and identify the name, physical address, and any internet address of the business or entity; and 4. The structure of any entity that Defendant has any ownership interest in or controls directly or indirectly that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Order, including: creation, merger, sale, or dissolution of the entity or any subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order.

requirements.description: Must submit notice to the Commission of filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding within 14 days of its filing
requirements.quoted_text: Defendant must submit to the Commission notice of the filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding by or against such Defendant within 14 days of its filing.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain records for any business owned or controlled for fifteen years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, and compliance records, retaining each record for five years.

requirements.description: Must create records for fifteen years after entry of Order and retain each record for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints and refund requests, and records demonstrating compliance with the Order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant must create certain records for fifteen (15) years after entry of the Order, and retain each such record for five (5) years. Specifically, for any business that Defendant individually or collectively with any other defendant named in this matter is a majority owner or controls directly or indirectly, he must create and retain the following records: A. Accounting records showing the revenues from all goods or services sold; B. Personnel records showing, for each person providing services, whether as an employee or otherwise, that person's: name; addresses; telephone numbers; job title or position; dates of service; and (if applicable) the reason for termination; C. Records of all consumer complaints and refund requests, whether received directly or indirectly, such as through a third party, and any response; and D. All records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including all submissions to the Commission.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiffs are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through discovery, depositions, document production, interviews, and other investigative means, including posing as consumers.

requirements.description: Within 14 days of written request from Plaintiff representative, Defendant must submit additional compliance reports or information sworn under penalty of perjury, appear for depositions, and produce documents for inspection and copying
requirements.quoted_text: Within 14 days of receipt of a written request from a representative of a Plaintiff, Defendant must: submit additional compliance reports or other requested information, which must be sworn under penalty of perjury; appear for depositions; and produce documents for inspection and copying. Plaintiffs are also authorized to obtain discovery, without further leave of court, using any of the procedures prescribed by Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 29, 30 (including telephonic depositions), 31, 33, 34, 36, 45, and 69.

requirements.description: Plaintiffs may communicate directly with Defendant and Defendant must permit Plaintiff representatives to interview employees or affiliated persons who agree to interviews
requirements.quoted_text: For matters concerning this Order, Plaintiffs are authorized to communicate directly with the Defendant. Defendant must permit representatives of any Plaintiff to interview any employee or other person affiliated with any Defendant who has agreed to such an interview. The person interviewed may have counsel present.

requirements.description: Plaintiffs may pose as consumers, suppliers, or other entities to Defendant or affiliated persons without identification or prior notice
requirements.quoted_text: Plaintiffs may use all other lawful means, including posing, through its representatives as consumers, suppliers, or other individuals or entities, to Defendant or any individual or entity affiliated with Defendant, without the necessity of identification or prior notice.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

requirements.description: Court retains jurisdiction for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

duration.termination_text: For twenty (20) years after entry of this Order, Defendant must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within 14 days of any change in the following:
